description: The conversation demonstrates how ClauseClear processes a homebuyer’s real‑estate purchase agreement, extracts key clauses (price, inspection, financing, default penalties), provides plain‑language summaries, flags risky language, and delivers a markdown briefing.

messages.content: You are ClauseClear, an AI assistant that helps users understand legal contracts. Use the provided tools to upload PDFs, extract text, parse clauses, summarize them in plain language, flag risky provisions, and export a concise briefing in markdown or PDF.

Hi, I just bought a house and received a Purchase Agreement. I need a plain‑language summary that highlights the purchase price, any inspection contingencies, financing terms, and any risky default penalties. I’ve attached the PDF (service_agreement.pdf).
Got it! I’ll upload the PDF and start processing.
PDF uploaded. Extracting the full text now.

{"contract_text": "
PURCHASE PRICE
The Buyer shall pay $425,000.00 to the Seller upon closing.

INSPECTION CONTINGENCY
This Agreement is contingent upon the Buyer obtaining a satisfactory home inspection within 10 days of execution. If the inspection reveals defects, Buyer may terminate the Agreement and receive a full refund of any earnest money.

FINANCING
Buyer’s obligation to close is contingent upon Buyer obtaining a conventional loan for at least 80% of the purchase price on terms no less favorable than customary. If financing is not secured by the closing date, Buyer may request an extension of up to 5 business days.

DEFAULT PENALTIES
If Buyer fails to close without a valid financing or inspection contingency, Buyer shall forfeit the earnest money and pay a liquidated damages penalty equal to 5% of the purchase price.

OTHER TERMS..."}
Text extracted. I’ll now identify the relevant clauses.

summaries.summary_text: You will pay $425,000 for the house, due at the closing meeting.
You have 10 days to get a home inspection. If the inspector finds problems, you can cancel the deal and get back any earnest money you’ve paid.
You must secure a conventional mortgage for at least 80% of the price on normal terms. If you don’t get the loan by the closing date, you can ask for a 5‑day extension.
If you walk away without a valid loan or inspection, you lose your earnest money and must also pay a penalty equal to 5% of the purchase price ($21,250).

risk_flags.explanation: A liquidated damages clause of 5% ($21,250) is higher than typical 1‑2% penalties and could be hard to negotiate.
risk_flags.mitigation: Consider negotiating the penalty down or adding a cure period before the penalty applies.

risk_flags.explanation: The clause allows only a 5‑day extension, which may be insufficient for many lenders.
risk_flags.mitigation: Ask for a longer extension (e.g., 10‑15 days) or a clause that waives penalty if the delay is due to lender processing times.
